Articles.Content:
Also:

Also I'm curious to see what upgradable buildings brings with it. Does this mean we may eventually have the ability to build our own space centers elsewhere on Kerbin? *gasp* What about on other planets!?

This desire for space centers on other planets and such has been around for a really long time, and I honestly don't think it's going to happen. I don't really think it's worth it, and the need for it isn't that huge.

i'd like to see highly trained kerbals doing easier, repetitive stuff on their own (aka integrate mechjeb)

after 30 launches, jeb should be perfectly capable of going to orbit on his own or raise his orbit.

To me the trick to getting this feature right is what gotcha get put in place this it.

I'd think as Kerbals get more skilled at part of the job they also focus more on that facet of the job but that focus would be to the detriment of other areas.

So take getting to orbit not as one skill but a whole bunch of them. Each one takes part of the focus of the Kerbal and because they are focused on those aspects they can't focus on other things. So a gun pilot to get in to orbit would need to be able to focus on holding coarse, coarse changes (by node), planning coarse changes like when push over for gravity turn (set node), Throttle and Staging. A Kerbal who focuses on all those things wouldn't have time for science or seeing if parts have broken, she just wants to fly to the point that she could only fly space station supply runs or probe supervision at mission control.

So a Kerbal focused on science might want to EVA just as a Kerbal pilot wants to punch the accelerator for a node and now we know how those Kerbals end up in funny orbits and need rescuing.
Can we have the TGA texture glitch caused by .25 addressed?

Seems (unless we have more secret features) that assuming the editor functions are nearly done, that we might get this update in-time for halloween or "____ de la moerte" for squad in Mexico (srry for not remembering completely the name). Maybe if there aren't too many null reference exceptions and such for the testers to discover otherwise we might get it for american Thx giving... this is just personal speculation..

Keep it up, and squash those bugs !

I consider it very unlikely to be released by the end of this month, they just started working on it. My bet is sometime in December. Sorry to burst your bubble.

Can we have the TGA texture glitch caused by .25 addressed?

I haven't heard of that glitch yet. Can someone explain it to me?

Edited October 16, 2014 by Engineer Of Stuff

That's the player's learning curve you're describing. You're controlling the rocket, and I imagine you're far better at getting your junk into the sky now than you were day one. You're the astronaut.

So Kerbal experience becomes meaningless. If it exists, it has to do something. Improving rockets ISP shouldn't be one of those things, as no amount of pilot proficiency will do that. Making docking easier, however, can be one of them - as long as we assume docking in the Kerbal Space Program is done manually. We could say "realism!" and realize docking would be done with an autopilot - enter Mechjeb.

I haven't heard of that glitch yet. Can someone explain it to me

I think he is referring to the stretched ground textures in some places, like Kerbin's deserts or some parts of MÃƒÂ¼n.

Cool, allowing switching between mirror and radial symmetry will make it nice and easy to construct a spaceplane+rocket in a single building.

Not completely sold on the "Kerbal Experience", will have to wait and see how it works. Seems there's not that many different avenues you could pursue in terms of passive bonuses... maybe an experienced pilot gains your ship a little more torque? Extra fuel efficiency? I'd be happy to just have a log for each Kerbal of the missions he's been on and the places he's gone, no bonuses needed.

Biomes everywhere sounds good, but really needs to be coupled with some system in stock for detecting which biome you're currently in and/or mapping biomes. The current system just feels so... arbitrary. "Oh look, I crossed a magical line in the ground and now I'm apparently on a SLOPE rather than a MIDLAND."

Really looking forward to the integration of the Fine Print mod, hadn't heard of it before but sounds exactly like the sort of thing I've been wanting in stock KSP career mode for months.

Edited October 16, 2014 by Kerano

I haven't heard of that glitch yet. Can someone explain it to me

Parts with tga textures on them sometimes load in with a white diffuse texture. (normal and specular mapping textures load up fine)

I think he is referring to the stretched ground textures in some places, like Kerbin's deserts or some parts of MÃƒÂ¼n.

No there is a glitch where some users get white parts if TGA texture is used. I've never seen it, but others have confirmed and it is a known issue. IE, Squad knows .25 caused the problem, I was just complaining here in case they decide to remember to fix it.

That's a system I could get behind. Spend XP to get a kerbal's Nuclear Rocket certification, then he can operate an LV-N powered ship.

Same here; I like this idea. It gives "trainer" designs more value, too. Fly a simple airplane around for a while before they let you take Skylon for a spin.

That's a system I could get behind. Spend XP to get a kerbal's Nuclear Rocket certification, then he can operate an LV-N powered ship.

This is such a good idea. The more I think about it the more I like it. You could have all sorts of certifications. To make it a little easier, you could certify Kerbals at launch if they'd gained enough XP.

Warning! You cannot use the RCS ports on this ship with these Kerbals onboard, because none of them are RCS certified. What would you like to do?

[ Launch Anyway ] [ Certify A Crewmember ] [ Modify Launching Crew ]

There will need to be errors in flight as well, when you swap crew on Mun the game needs to tell you why suddenly RCS stops working.
Someone needs to change .26 to .90 on the title!

This is such a good idea. The more I think about it the more I like it. You could have all sorts of certifications. To make it a little easier, you could certify Kerbals at launch if they'd gained enough XP.

Warning! You cannot use the RCS ports on this ship with these Kerbals onboard, because none of them are RCS certified. What would you like to do?

[ Launch Anyway ] [ Certify A Crewmember ] [ Modify Launching Crew ]

There will need to be errors in flight as well, when you swap crew on Mun the game needs to tell you why suddenly RCS stops working.

It feels to much like a completely new feature, but as we do not know what K-EX (Kerbal Experience, attempt to set a new abb. ... ) will do, one cannot be sure how far fetched this idea is - although they spoke about "how the ship performs", which regretfully sounds (now that I had a night to sleep over this thought) a bit to much like "fuel efficiency".

As the Kerbals XP influence influences something in KSP is a wildly discussed topic in here i'd give my 2 cents on that too.

Personally i like the idea of Kerbals lvl'in up not that much, but if it is planned in terms of can Kerbal X fly ship Y or kan Kerbal Z do research on Material U i'd really like the idea of it.

I Expect a kind of "How should i group my crew to get it efficient" would be very nice.

An example : You got 5 Kerbonauts, 2 of them have experience in being Captain and "flying" the spacecraft, those 2 are the only that can fly crafts above a 50T mass or something.

You got 2 of those Kerbs that are more the research guys, they boost your science output or are as only kerbs legitimated to to research (Mobile ResearchLab) on the picked up surface material.

The last Kerbonauty is trained to do Work in his spacesiut, he is more experienced in this and uses a) less monopropellant and "manouvers" better ( c)As lifesupport is not of relevance i'd leave that open).

You could also split competences into flying/docking

As i said just my 2 cents in terms what i'd like the Kerbal XP to be

This qualification idea is the only idea aside from explicit automation (i.e.: the kerbal actually piloting like MechJeb, minus the mech (which I am perfectly fine with, as it is a choice to use or not use). I'm entirely against any "buffs" due to skill, I'd turn that off, and never even try it (or wait for the mod that does).

Qualification is interesting, though.

Kerbal Experience... Does not yet seem to be conceptualised with a complete systems view. Here's my perspective, YMMV. "Apollogies" to the TL;DRers

My perspective is that astro/cosmo/nauts are mostly passengers rather than pilots. For example, the Apollo crews were trained extensively in the operation of the guidance computer. They loaded specific programs and parameters during flight to control the attitude, transfer and orbital parameters. If they (and more importantly Mission Control) agreed with what the computer indicated, the pushed the PROCEED button not a control stick. If necessary, they could have flown the mission autonomously (however Mission Control would not have been pleased). The experience to achieve this was not solely based on a specific individual but rather on the collective intelligence and capability of the entire extended Space program.

Today, nearly ALL space missions are flown autonomously with few exceptions. There too many dynamic flight events occurring. Astro/cosmo/nauts are focused on monitoring the automatic systems and engaging backups or manual over-rides during failures.

So in KSP, Our Kerbals must be trained in the operation of every piece of equipment and every mission step prior to the launch. We must spent time and Funds to make this happen. If not, then they are only Cargo (scientists, tourists, engineers, etc. being transported to a destination)

Other training can occur surrounding specific things like space walks ( A Kerbal must be trained to spacewalk in order to retrieve things like Goo or Materials). They would not be allowed to EVA even after Landing (perhaps except on Lathe where falling out of the lander without a helmet is actually an option)

From a flight only perspective, having trained Kerbals on a mission would help insure against equipment failures. If the KGNU (Kerbal Guidance and Navigation Unit) failed (and the backup KGNU failed also) then a well trained Kerbal could control the attitude and orbit to complete the mission. Also, their proficiency in operating the onboard systems could be reflected by increased accuracy of manoeuvre nodes or additionally the inclusion of more accurate trajectory projections, dynamically updated landing targets etc.

Landings on the other hand represent an interesting perspective. If the data is available, an autonomous landing is likely. But in the event of obstructions in the target landing zone, the player would likely take over control to assure landing safely. This would represent the Kerbal grabbing the flight stick (just like the final seconds in all the manned Lunar landings).

After having invested a wealth of Funds in a specific Kerbal, then that Kerbal is a valuable asset which must be protected otherwise there could be a great loss of reputation. This opens the opportunity for a new building at KSC to house the KSP Insurance Agency!

Another factor to consider is the practice of training the crew together as a unit along with a backup crew - something to think about.

All of the above could give more purpose to the astronaut complex in game.

I am not advocating an EVE Online type system, but the Eve implementation does better mimic the real world albeit in a hyper-SciFi manner.

AnyWHoos... Those are my thoughts, hope it helps the dialogue.

Cheers,

W.

Edited October 16, 2014 by Wallygator
Schpelling

part rotations during construction

I'm more bothered about that during flight. mmm...perhaps I should learn to mod and do that.
I like the merging of the SPH and the VAB. It will become far simpler to build space-shuttles!

Throwing my two cents into the ring, I'm in the camp that would really prefer Kerbal experience to not alter the laws of physics. Isp, Thrust, Torque, etc, should only be affected by how well you build the part, not who you crew it with. I'm totally on board with ideas like better collection/transmission of science, lab work, reputation gains/losses, etc.

I'm not quite sure how I feel about the version number jumping all the way to 0.90.0 given that it implies relatively few beta releases before the big 1.0. While I realize that it is always possible to go 0.10x.x, the perception is that 0.99.x is the penultimate release. If you were to go to 0.75 or similar, it would still be a big jump, but leave much more room before that perception hits. Also, it would let you have fun with version 0.88.x

I'm excited by the announcement that Aerodynamics rework is in the cards, and I hope it produces a "realistic" effect (sleek is good, clunky is bad, drag doesn't change as a function of mass, nosecones help, etc). I'd be pumped if FAR-like structural failures were added as an option. I share others thoughts that re-entry heat (and heatshields), Isp affecting thrust instead of fuel consumption, and some form of life support would be good candidates for addition to stock. Difficulty adjustments could be added for deadliness/consumption rates/consequences.

One thing I'd love to see is the tech tree getting opened up a bit to allow mods to add nodes like the old Treeloader mod did. This would give modders more freedom with how to mix their parts into the tech progression, and reduce the potential for conflict between mod changes to the tree.

Ok, more than two cents... maybe a quarter?

Nw to tell the community about the 0.26 update, SQUAD AWAY!

*Superman Theme*

*facepalm

We need a thread just for kerbal experience discussion. I used to think that ISP and such were the only real upgrades until some of the discussion here. Now I see that those would be a bad idea, even if i dont share designs with other people.

Im not going to lie, part rotation being easier will save me HOURS of work designing ships, but I dont think its something we want all that much, compared to other things *cough*Mk3 Plane Parts*cough*. I do, however, like that you guys are finally moving into beta, a huge step for many games that is a cumulation of years of work, and for that, I say "Congrats"

Im not going to lie, part rotation being easier will save me HOURS of work designing ships, but I dont think its something we want all that much, compared to other things *cough*Mk3 Plane Parts*cough*.

For me, the improved building experience is the most exciting thing mentioned in the OP. Not only smarter part rotation, but being able to switch between VAB & SPH setups, ie 4 x symmetry in the SPH! This is going to make a huge difference, much more so than some parts.

I'm still loving the ALT key activating node attachment-only option, which is amazing. But tbh, I spend more time building than 'playing', so these things make a big difference for me.

I'm hoping these updates to the VAB mean that I can move parts by small degrees using keys instead of the mouse, so that I can place something in just the right spot without worrying about the mouse slipping a tiny bit and placing it a fraction of a hair off (or sometimes way, way off). Especially when it comes to things like structural panels, and if you place it in just the right spot, it'll put the two panels side-by-side, lined up, but if you move it just the tiniest bit, it rotates some crazy angle and clips through the other. I've rage-quit so many designs because of stuff like that.
What about a fix for all the flickery shadows?
